bestBHT.bht: In their pursuit of righteousness, the Jews stumbled and missed the mark because they sought it through their own works instead of through faith in Christ. They stumbled at the very obstacle that they had long prayed for—the Messiah. Their ignorance and rejection of Jesus as the stone of stumbling led to their downfall. The Jews' reliance on self-righteousness hindered them from receiving the gift of salvation that could only be attained through faith in Christ, causing them to neglect the true source of righteousness. This rejection of faith in Christ ultimately led to their downfall.

Jamieson-Fausset-Brown: Because they sought it not by faith, but as it were—rather simply, 'as' by the works of the law—as if it were thus attainable, which justification is not: Since, therefore, it is attainable only by faith, they missed it.
They stumbled at that stumbling-stone—better, 'against the stone of stumbling,' meaning Christ.
But in this they only did.
Albert Barnes: They sought it not by faith...They depended on their own righteousness, and not on the mercy of God to be obtained by faith.
The sacrifices had reference to a future state of things, and were doubtless so understood.
That was the rejection and the crucifixion of their own Messiah; their unwillingness to be saved by him; their contempt of him and his message.
Marvin Vincent: In their foolish course Israel thought they were advancing on a clear path, and lo! all at once there was found in this way an obstacle upon which they were broken..." (Godet).
...this obstacle was the very Messiah whom they had so long invoked in all their prayers" (Godet).
John Calvin: They are deservedly rejected, who attempt to attain salvation by trusting in their own works; for they, as far as they can, abolish faith, without which no salvation can be expected.
Whosoever obtrudes on God the righteousness of works, attempts to rob him of his own office.

When we claim for ourselves any righteousness we in a manner contend with the power of Christ; for his office is no less to beat down all the pride of the flesh, than to relieve and comfort those who labour and are wearied under their burden.
Archibald T. Robertson: They stumbled at the stone of stumbling."
The Jews found Christ a σκανδαλον."
John Gill: ...because, as they did not seek for righteousness in a right place, or object, they sought for it in the law, and the works of it, where it is never to be found by a sinful creature, and not in Christ, in whom only are righteousness and strength...

...they sought it as if they expected their justification before God was to be by works of righteousness done by them; or as if it was partly by their own works, and partly by the goodness of God, accepting of them for a justifying righteousness.

...meaning the word of the Gospel, at which Peter says they stumbled, and particularly the doctrine of justification by the righteousness of Christ; or rather Christ himself, who was 'to the Jews a stumbling block, and to the Greeks foolishness'.
John Wesley: Is it because God eternally decreed they should not?
Because they sought it not by faith - whereby alone it could be attained.
For they stumbled at that stumblingstone — Christ crucified.

bhtAttempts.bht: In their pursuit of righteousness, the Jews stumbled and missed the mark because they sought it through their own works instead of through faith in Christ. They stumbled at the very obstacle that they had long prayed for—the Messiah. Their ignorance and rejection of Jesus as the stone of stumbling led to their downfall. The Jews' reliance on self-righteousness hindered them from receiving the gift of salvation that could only be attained through faith in Christ, causing them to neglect the true source of righteousness. This rejection of faith in Christ ultimately led to their downfall.

The Jews stumbled in their pursuit of righteousness because they sought it through their own works instead of by faith in Christ. They stumbled at the very obstacle they had long prayed for—the Messiah. Their rejection of Jesus as the stone of stumbling hindered them from receiving salvation through faith in Him. By relying on self-righteousness, they neglected the true source of righteousness. This rejection ultimately led to their downfall, as they failed to recognize the need for faith in Christ for justification.

The stumbling of the Jews in their pursuit of righteousness stemmed from an approach based on the works of the law, rather than faith. Their misguided notion that justification could be attained by their own efforts led to their downfall. They stumbled against the stone of stumbling, Christ Himself, whom they had long awaited as the Messiah. Their rejection of faith in Him as the true source of righteousness hindered them from receiving salvation. This serves as a reminder that salvation can only be obtained through faith in Christ, not by works alone.

The Jews stumbled in their pursuit of righteousness because they sought it through their own works instead of through faith in Christ. Their rejection of Jesus as the stone of stumbling hindered them from receiving salvation through faith in Him. By relying on self-righteousness, they neglected the true source of righteousness. This rejection ultimately led to their downfall, as they failed to recognize the need for faith in Christ for justification.

The Jews stumbled in their pursuit of righteousness because they sought it not by faith in Christ, but by relying on their own works and the law. In their ignorance, they failed to recognize that justification could only be attained through faith, rather than by their own efforts. The stumbling-stone they encountered was none other than the very Messiah they had fervently prayed for. Their rejection of faith in Christ led to their downfall, as they missed the true path to salvation and righteousness.
